newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Brussels Bel-20 to consolidate until next week.
newsitem.headline: Brussels Bel-20 to consolidate until next week.

text.p: Belgian shares, which fell on Thursday on the back of weaker world stock and bond markets, were expected to see further consolidation into next week, but could then rise again.
"This is what we need, it's good for the health of the market after recent crazy runs, but then we'll go back up again," said one trader at a major Belgian bank.

The blue-chip Bel-20 .BFX index, which has seen 25 record closing highs so far this year, ended down 0.85 percent, or 18.79 points, at 2,191.82, with a firm 3.3 billion francs worth of Belgian shares traded.
Dealers said the bourse would follow the direction of Wall Street .DJI and European markets, but could start rising after a bout of profit-taking as more cash was expected to come into the market.
"Brussels will follow New York, and if Wall Street continues to fall, we'll follow suit," said one trader.
The focus was on bank shares as some investors took profits after recent bull runs which were spurred on by speculation of a merger in the sector, particularly between Generale Bank and rival BBL.
Generale Bank closed down 1.3 percent at 13,525 and BBL ended down 0.2 percent at 8,340 francs.
Attention had also focused on Kredietbank which after the bourse close said 1996 group net profit up 13.5 percent, this was somewhat better than market expectations.
Kredietbank closed up 0.38 percent at 13,250 francs.
Kredietbank denied market talk that it was in merger talks with French Credit Commercial de France (CCF), adding that both banks had been "good friends" for many years.
Elsewhere, the Bel-20's main loser, steel cord and wire maker Bekaert, fell 3.08 percent to 22,000 francs.
Dealers said the share fell after investors decided to take profits after recent sharp rises and a weaker dollar.
Retailer GIB GBIBt.RB fell 3.1 percent to 1,585 francs, with investors taking profits after recent sharp rises.
Another large loser, oil and chemicals group Petrofina closed down 2.43 percent at 12,050 francs, on the back of profit-taking, weaker oil prices and a lower dollar.
But polyurethane foam maker Recticel's preferred share jumped 9.2 percent to 441 francs after better than expected 1996 results and upgrade ratings from major Belgian institutions.
